The brig Nile, from Canton, and last from Mon
tevideo, where she was detained l8 to 20 days by
the Brazilian squadron, has arrived at Boston. She
left the hitter place August 22d. Six Brazilian
vessels of war we're al that port Admiral Pinto
Guedes was off Bneuo. Ayres, with frigate, a
soop of war, three niasted schooner, and several
smaller vessels, some of which were ordered to
cruise night and day. The Rio Saluda was block
AIDED by fIigate and some small craft SO that the
Buenes Ayreans found it very difficult to get their
prizes to port, several of which we're burnt about
the beginning of August. The Patagonia squadron
was daily expected at Montevideo. The Brazilians
were actively employed in repairing the Notifications
SO that it was supposed that the war would continue
a long time. Supplies were abundant, and business
dull.


The expectation of gold and silver from Buenos
Ayres was prevented by the most vigorous mea-
sures, and new duties was laid on some species Of
merchandise.

acquisitions Of Russia as likely to affect at some -
tpre time, the possessions Of Britain in India. But
when the vast deserts are remembered, which inn
pede hr march in that quater it seems likely that
more tempting prize socits her in Turkey. With
out port on the Mediterranean, CUnstantnople
would be the most desirable of acquisitions for her.
1t would unietter the commerce of the Black Sea,
and give her the key to that great nursery the Med
tc"ranean of the navigation and the civilization of
antien times and the gre of vast and fertile coasts,
at this day Astounding in all the material of ofcommerce.
That she looks this sGolden Horn" of the city Of
Constantine, with desiring eyes, is quite unquesti
enable and the liberation of Greece itself is by no
means so important question to the European pow
ers as how to secure to themselves portion Of the
spoil (Which Russia stands most convenient to seize
that the decadence of Turkey must presently place
at the mercy of the strongest.

MR. EDITOR: With a very large number of cit
izens, paid my respects to the President last even
ling, at MIR. Barnum's. He received US with cor
From, the National LateLlieencer.

OF JERUSALEM.


Within the last three years several plans have
been formed in Europe, for re-estabshing the order
Of St. John. For long series Of years previously
to the capture of Malta by Bonaparte, the knights
had been gradually losing their power and territories
Once the proud owners of stately castles in Pales-
tine, and SYRIA and the isles Of the Mediterranean,
the champions of the cross and the scourges of the
Ottoman, the gallant opposers of the mighty Soy-
man, they have for many years been an evidence
amongst others, that the great wheel of change
spares nothing earth, but rolls alike valor
and honor, and pride, and strength, and power.
crushing the towers of the mighty, as we'll as the
cottages of the lowly.


In the Gazette de France" of Aug 81, we
find an article relative to Algiers. 1t recommends
the occupation of Algers by the christians, and
that it should be put under the dominion of the
knights of ST. John.--ss In the re-establishment Of
this order,'' says the writer trust for the main
tenance eff the conquest, and have read with plea
sure a letter from VIENNA stating that certain
great power is about to adopt this principle of re-
establishment, although mention is made of the
future location of the order which is nevertheless
matter of considerable question" The writer then
considers and answers the objections agans the or
der of st. John-the VOW of celibacy, and the mix
ture of religious with military character Having
answered these, He then considers the claims which
| the European powers who may unite in conquering
Algers. would advance for their share of the prize,
and argues that they trfng in comparison with
the advantages which would arise from bestowing
the state upon the knights of st. John.


The close of the article is worthy of translation.
"The political existence of Algiers is incompatible
with the quiet, the civilization, and the dignity of
Europe besides, her piratica insolence has exceed
ed all bounds-she deserves an exemplary chastise-
ment.-FTaace cannot conquer Algiers for herself
alone, without exciting jeaousies prejudcial to that
union which the strength and safety of Europe de
pend. 1t is very easy for maritime confederation
to take Agers, and it is very difficult to form COM
mon government for the place. The order of st.
John of Jerusalem is the only institution which will
suit the purpose Its msfortunes, itslong services,
its ancient glory, its unjust deposition all plead in
its behalf, and christian Europe ought eagerly te
seize this opportunity for its re-estabishment. A.
gainst the bulwark of Mussuman piracy, good sense
tells us to oppose bulwark of Christian commerce.
s'Algiers, more valuable than Rhodes or Malta,
ought to be an indemnity for the losses of an order.
dear to the Christian world 1t is not impossible
! that the first moments of its re-estabshment may
be attended with troubles, and amongst the proba


bilities we must place the appgehensons, and per


haps the resistance of the Crescent. But unless


misapprehend the power of religion and patriotism
r and that ancient chvalrous honor which is unkno


to feudality we shall find La Vaettes L'Isle Adams
and D'Aubussons* where the enemies of the Chris
:. tian name will not find Dragut or Baroarossa'
*Vaette L'Isc Adams and d. Aubusson were formerl,
Grand Masters of the Order OF ST. John of Jerusalem, and
distinguished The first Grand Master the cele
bated Raymond of 1houlousi part of tile oah taker
o by the Knight was "never reckon number OF the


enemy, and to die rather than surrender"

From the Npw- Fork Morning Courier.
ALGIERS AND THE KNIGHTS OF ST. JOHN


OF JERIJSAI.EM

Russia.-The statement below, of the amount of
Russian commerce, is from the London Courier.
The progress of this empire in civilization, and the
extension of its frontiers all sides, within the last


century, are the more interesting as they seem to
have received their impulse from the genius Of single
man. 1t was Peter l., who conquered provinces in
order to obtain port for his dominions, that gave


the first movement to that policy which has been so
consistently pursued BY his successors. M The posi-


territorial grandeur. The limit of European civili-
zaton to the east, she has on several parts of her
frontier such weak and unpoHced neighbors, (if we
NAV use the expression that she can hardly fail to
come out Of every conflict with them. with new ac-


misitions. The event of her present war with Per-
sa will show this truth, and still farther extend the
dominion which she has been pushing with such sue
cess in that part Of the world
II was once the fashion Of the day, to regard the
From the Baltimore american.

liam squadron upon merchant vessel OF this coun-
try, pursuing lawful trade, within the rules ac-
knowIedged by the government, appears to US to
call for the prompt interference of our own govern
ment to seek redress.


1t will be recollected that an understanding had
been established between the Brazilian government
and Capt. Bdde, representative in the La Plata,
that American vessels bound to Buenos Ayres,
should not be considered liable to arrest, unless
being warned off and their papers endorsed, they
should attempt second time to enter the blockad-
ed port.


The brig Nile, Capt. forbes, belonging to Messrs.
J. u /. ii. Perkins Il Sons left Canton for Boston,
in March last with orders to stop at Buenos Ayres
to dispose OF such part of her cargo saleable,
and to proceed with the remainder to Boston. The
Nile entered the La Plata and met with nothing TO
INFORM her OF the blockade until within few miles
of Buenos Ayres, where she found the Brazilian
squadron at anchor; they boarded and informed him
OF the blockade !; his papers showed the property
to be Americana his orders also gave evidence that
he was to violate no beligerent right, yet contrary
to the usage which has been pursued, he order
ed to Mentevideo, under convoy OF four vessels OF
war, the Brazilian Commodore declaring at the
same time that he did not consider him as prize,
and leaving him in the command of his vessel and
crew. During The passage he separated from
the convoy by thick weather, and had frequent op-
portunities of evadng the Brazilian vessels of
war. and of proceeding on his voyage to Boston,
bringing with him the midshipman who was sent in
charge of his papers, had he been so disposed hut
conhding in the perfect fairness and lawfulness of his
proceedings, that he had not intended and had not


in fact violated any begerent right, and that the
Commodore Of the Brazilian squadron was also sat


stied of the innocence of his conduct and intentions
and trusting in the assurances he had given him to
this effect, he voluntarily proceeded in good faith
with his own to Muntevideo, and actually
| reached there 24 hours before the convoy. Here
he found the U. S. ship Boston, Captain Hoffman
Before proceeding board the ship of the Brazil
ian Admiral he waited on Capt Hoffman, who as,
sured him that the conduct pursued towards ouI
countrymen in similar circumstances, had been such
as to justify the belief that his papers would be i'm
mediately returned to HIM, aud his vessel suffered
to proceed to Boston without delay, advising him tc
deliver his papers to the Brazilian Admiral, Capt


Forbes having previously demanded and received


them from the mldshipman. He accordingly pro


ceeded on board the Admral's ship and delivered


them to him, who said all was right, somethn:


to that effect. His astonishment may then be i'm


agined, on beholdng the next day, without any pre-


vious notice or form, his vessel taken possession


by two armed launches, brought in near the shore


and anchored in an unsafe position, her sails un


bent, though wet and sent on shore to rot, and thl
gang proceeded to unhang the rudder, and dsmantl
. the vessel This was the situation Of affairs at tn
last dates what may be the result can only be cor
jectured.


y Every vessel before warned off had been give
up, but it is apprehended the cupidity of the Ae


mral had prevented the liberation of this vessel,
: her cargo was of great value compared with tn


value Of the cargoes, generally entering the La n;
. ia, having cost in China more than hundred thor
# sand dollars. We understand representation hi
y been made to the government at Washington on til
subject and there is no doubt that prompt measure
a will be taken to interfere for the preservation of til
~ property. Having no apprehensions of such 8
y outrage, the owners, we believe, are not insure
N N against any other than the usual pers of the sea-

address was as singular as MIR. Adams reply was

.qbridgcment of Scotl's Napoleon-An abridge-
ment of this youminous work has just been publish
ed in New York. 1t s comprised in closely pr,n-
ted octave volume of $50 pages. The plan adopt
ed by the editor has been to omit, in the first place.
the preliminary view ofthe French revolution, an
event in which Bonaparte had but little share, and
the account of which, in the pages of Scott mark
ed by some unfayorable statements against Lafay-
ette In the second place, he has excluded certain
irrelevant political d'squistioDs and narratives OF
events of collateral nature and not Immediately
connected with the life of Napoleon. In the third
place, two, and sometimes four chapters have been
united into one, and their headings abbreviated.
The editor observes that he has been studous to
tain all the facts which have an immediate connec-
tion with the Of Napoleon, and these are CIV
en- in the very language of the author Of Waverly.
From the Viiiage Record.


We publish Mr.. Eatons letter entire, not because
we see, in the greater part of it, any thing to
mand special attention. but because it has been long
and anxously looked for, and believe the reader
will like to the whole Of it, The public were led
to believe it would have important bearing upon
the Presidential question. To US appears to
tain very little. touching that matter merely. Two
things stated are. however, important. The avow-
al that Mr.. Eaton furnished the editor OF the Coum-
bian Observer fifteen hundred dollars! And the
declaration that Mr.. Buchanan proposed to fight
the opponents of General Jackson with their.own
weapons-that is. by intrigue, &c. This is denied.
and we cannot but believe, that Mr.. Eaton, in this
particular, msconceived Mr.. Buchanan--a7olt
will be remarked that the letter does not, in the
| smallest degree. go to raise a suspicion that Mr..
Clay made any proposition to General jackson
through Mr.. Buchanan ; and this, be it remembered
is the great question at issue between GEN. Jackson
and the public. --


| The editor oftbe Z" Courier published in Por-
tage, Ohio, says. We are well assured, that ut
least two-hrs of both branches of the next Legis-
laure of Ohio will be in favor of the reelection Of
Mr.. Adams. There seventeen members Of the
senate, whose term of service have not yet expred
tareLve ofwhom, and probably thirteen are admins
tration men. Of the nineteen districts from which
the senators are to be chosed at the approaching
election not less than twelve will give majortes in
favour of the administration. OF the representa-
tives to the next congress romthis stateeLeUea
in favour of the administration, and too opposed TO
it." So much for Ohio. q. S. Gazette.

gers of the Wilmngton Union Colonization Society,


will be held at the house of the Hon. Willard Hall,

Il. A. HEM DERSON, Register.

OREENSVILLE, y. Y. OCt. o'


More Gold.-We have just seen small bar OF
very line Gold, exceeding in value one hundred and
fifty dollars, brought from Tiger river in Spartan
burg, where Mr.. James II. Randolph, is now wash
ing for this metal. This piece of Gold was not
found in one body, but consists Of several parcels
melted into one.
GREENsvILLE, S. c. Oct. G..

any reason why be should he preferred to any Of
the statesmen iDthe country protesting the same la
:tudinous construction.


Your committee will also declare, that after ex-
confidence in the Integrity and honor Of the secre-
tary Of State.

reason Wny .uC niouN kiC'cAS' ~ any b'
he statesmen Dthe country protesting the same la
.itudinous construction.


Your committee will also declare, that, after ex-
amining all the proofs, they have still the most entire
confidence in the Integrity and honor Of the Secre.
tary Of State.


From the papers itappears that, in some parts OF
our country the result Of the late election in this
State was unexpected. II must be admitted that
MIR. Adams had been represented in the worst col
ors for three years. and that these representations
original and selected, had gone, perhaps, to every
village in the state while little, in comparison, Of
a contrary nature had been presented TO our citi-
zens.--Certain individuals, also, who had con-
siderable influence, we're known TO be members Of
the I" Combination in full standing: and this Cir
cum.,ance in addition to the former, was supposed
10 be decisive of the fate of Mr.. Adams in Dela-
ware.


But the truth Notwithstanding all the misrep-
reseptations of prostuted press--and all the la
bours of the Combination" asprants among us,
Delaware has not been at any one moment, friend
" to the election Of General Jackson in preference
to Mr. Adams Had not the people of this State
been able to form their sentiments on this sub
ject, they still would have remembered the denun-
Citations of the General which proceeded from this
same prostuted press, and these political asprans
and some of their tools. The people remembered
these things--and they will long remember them,
unless they willing to submit to further imposi-
tions.


Let, therefore, writers at distance not suppose
that they have "ga,ned" Delaware--for Delaware
was never in favour of General Jackson, notwth-
Standing althe labors of prosttuted press and its
Managers all the tales Of kremer Jackson, lsaacks,
Eaton, and company and all the misrepresentation
selected from the Kentucky Argus, Noahs Enquir-
er, and the whole host of =" improved presses, and
circulated semi-weekly, in all parts of the State.


1t is true, that there parts of the State which
need more fair, Just, and candid view of public
men and measures. 1t is true-that things as they
really are have not been presented to them but it
would be an unjust estimate of the sober sense, the
dsnterested feeling, and intelligence of the people
of Delaware, to suppose that they were incapable Of
discovering that the prominent leaders, in the war
waging against the Administration we're PERSON
ALL Interested Ill ulC cfcht VI tC Sohtcoi ACJ
have seen. nd we'll weighed this striking circum-
sance and they have told, even. those whom they
have delighted to honor, that they are FREEMEN,
not to be led or driven in this momentous question.
They have spoken amidst all the disadvantages un-
der which they have labored, by majority OF near
k 400; and they will hereafter speak, when pos
sessed Of more just and true state of things, with
more decision

Once the proud owners of stately castles in Pales-

man, they have for many years been an evidence
amongst others, that the great wheel of change
spares nothing earth, but rolls alike valor
and honor, and pride, and strength, and power.
crushing the towers of the mighty, as we'll as the
cottages of the lowly.


In the Gazette de France" of Aug 81, we
find an article relative to Algiers. 1t recommends
the occupation of Algers by the christians, and
that it should be put under the dominion of the
knights of ST. John.--ss In the re-establishment Of
this order,'' says the writer trust for the main
tenance eff the conquest, and have read with plea
sure a letter from VIENNA stating that certain
great power is about to adopt this principle of re-
establishment, although mention is made of the
future location of the order which is nevertheless
matter of considerable question" The writer then
considers and answers the objections agans the or
der of st. John-the VOW of celibacy, and the mix
ture of religious with military character Having
answered these, He then considers the claims which
| the European powers who may unite in conquering
Algers. would advance for their share of the prize,
and argues that they trfng in comparison with
the advantages which would arise from bestowing
the state upon the knights of st. John.


The close of the article is worthy of translation.
"The political existence of Algiers is incompatible
with the quiet, the civilization, and the dignity of
Europe besides, her piratica insolence has exceed
ed all bounds-she deserves an exemplary chastise-
ment.-FTaace cannot conquer Algiers for herself
alone, without exciting jeaousies prejudcial to that
union which the strength and safety of Europe de
pend. 1t is very easy for maritime confederation
to take Agers, and it is very difficult to form COM
mon government for the place. The order of st.
John of Jerusalem is the only institution which will
suit the purpose Its msfortunes, itslong services,
its ancient glory, its unjust deposition all plead in
its behalf, and christian Europe ought eagerly te
seize this opportunity for its re-estabishment. A.
gainst the bulwark of Mussuman piracy, good sense
tells us to oppose bulwark of Christian commerce.
s'Algiers, more valuable than Rhodes or Malta,
ought to be an indemnity for the losses of an order.
dear to the Christian world 1t is not impossible
! that the first moments of its re-estabshment may
be attended with troubles, and amongst the proba


bilities we must place the appgehensons, and per


haps the resistance of the Crescent. But unless


misapprehend the power of religion and patriotism
r and that ancient chvalrous honor which is unkno


to feudality we shall find La Vaettes L'Isle Adams
and D'Aubussons* where the enemies of the Chris
:. tian name will not find Dragut or Baroarossa'
*Vaette L'Isc Adams and d. Aubusson were formerl,
Grand Masters of the Order OF ST. John of Jerusalem, and
distinguished The first Grand Master the cele
bated Raymond of 1houlousi part of tile oah taker
o by the Knight was "never reckon number OF the


enemy, and to die rather than surrender"

Russia.-The statement below, of the amount of
Russian commerce, is from the London Courier.
The progress of this empire in civilization, and the
extension of its frontiers all sides, within the last


century, are the more interesting as they seem to
have received their impulse from the genius Of single
man. 1t was Peter l., who conquered provinces in
order to obtain port for his dominions, that gave


the first movement to that policy which has been so
consistently pursued BY his successors. M The posi-


territorial grandeur. The limit of European civili-
zaton to the east, she has on several parts of her
frontier such weak and unpoHced neighbors, (if we
NAV use the expression that she can hardly fail to
come out Of every conflict with them. with new ac-


misitions. The event of her present war with Per-
sa will show this truth, and still farther extend the
dominion which she has been pushing with such sue
cess in that part Of the world

full articles.headline: From the Boston DAILY .Adpertiser.
full articles.article:
liam squadron upon merchant vessel OF this coun-
try, pursuing lawful trade, within the rules ac-
knowIedged by the government, appears to US to
call for the prompt interference of our own govern
ment to seek redress.


1t will be recollected that an understanding had
been established between the Brazilian government
and Capt. Bdde, representative in the La Plata,
that American vessels bound to Buenos Ayres,
should not be considered liable to arrest, unless
being warned off and their papers endorsed, they
should attempt second time to enter the blockad-
ed port.


The brig Nile, Capt. forbes, belonging to Messrs.
J. u /. ii. Perkins Il Sons left Canton for Boston,
in March last with orders to stop at Buenos Ayres
to dispose OF such part of her cargo saleable,
and to proceed with the remainder to Boston. The
Nile entered the La Plata and met with nothing TO
INFORM her OF the blockade until within few miles
of Buenos Ayres, where she found the Brazilian
squadron at anchor; they boarded and informed him
OF the blockade !; his papers showed the property
to be Americana his orders also gave evidence that
he was to violate no beligerent right, yet contrary
to the usage which has been pursued, he order
ed to Mentevideo, under convoy OF four vessels OF
war, the Brazilian Commodore declaring at the
same time that he did not consider him as prize,
and leaving him in the command of his vessel and
crew. During The passage he separated from
the convoy by thick weather, and had frequent op-
portunities of evadng the Brazilian vessels of
war. and of proceeding on his voyage to Boston,
bringing with him the midshipman who was sent in
charge of his papers, had he been so disposed hut
conhding in the perfect fairness and lawfulness of his
proceedings, that he had not intended and had not


in fact violated any begerent right, and that the
Commodore Of the Brazilian squadron was also sat


stied of the innocence of his conduct and intentions
and trusting in the assurances he had given him to
this effect, he voluntarily proceeded in good faith
with his own to Muntevideo, and actually
| reached there 24 hours before the convoy. Here
he found the U. S. ship Boston, Captain Hoffman
Before proceeding board the ship of the Brazil
ian Admiral he waited on Capt Hoffman, who as,
sured him that the conduct pursued towards ouI
countrymen in similar circumstances, had been such
as to justify the belief that his papers would be i'm
mediately returned to HIM, aud his vessel suffered
to proceed to Boston without delay, advising him tc
deliver his papers to the Brazilian Admiral, Capt


Forbes having previously demanded and received


them from the mldshipman. He accordingly pro


ceeded on board the Admral's ship and delivered


them to him, who said all was right, somethn:


to that effect. His astonishment may then be i'm


agined, on beholdng the next day, without any pre-


vious notice or form, his vessel taken possession


by two armed launches, brought in near the shore


and anchored in an unsafe position, her sails un


bent, though wet and sent on shore to rot, and thl
gang proceeded to unhang the rudder, and dsmantl
. the vessel This was the situation Of affairs at tn
last dates what may be the result can only be cor
jectured.


y Every vessel before warned off had been give
up, but it is apprehended the cupidity of the Ae


mral had prevented the liberation of this vessel,
: her cargo was of great value compared with tn


value Of the cargoes, generally entering the La n;
. ia, having cost in China more than hundred thor
# sand dollars. We understand representation hi
y been made to the government at Washington on til
subject and there is no doubt that prompt measure
a will be taken to interfere for the preservation of til
~ property. Having no apprehensions of such 8
y outrage, the owners, we believe, are not insure
N N against any other than the usual pers of the sea-

.qbridgcment of Scotl's Napoleon-An abridge-
ment of this youminous work has just been publish
ed in New York. 1t s comprised in closely pr,n-
ted octave volume of $50 pages. The plan adopt
ed by the editor has been to omit, in the first place.
the preliminary view ofthe French revolution, an
event in which Bonaparte had but little share, and
the account of which, in the pages of Scott mark
ed by some unfayorable statements against Lafay-
ette In the second place, he has excluded certain
irrelevant political d'squistioDs and narratives OF
events of collateral nature and not Immediately
connected with the life of Napoleon. In the third
place, two, and sometimes four chapters have been
united into one, and their headings abbreviated.
The editor observes that he has been studous to
tain all the facts which have an immediate connec-
tion with the Of Napoleon, and these are CIV
en- in the very language of the author Of Waverly.
From the Viiiage Record.


We publish Mr.. Eatons letter entire, not because
we see, in the greater part of it, any thing to
mand special attention. but because it has been long
and anxously looked for, and believe the reader
will like to the whole Of it, The public were led
to believe it would have important bearing upon
the Presidential question. To US appears to
tain very little. touching that matter merely. Two
things stated are. however, important. The avow-
al that Mr.. Eaton furnished the editor OF the Coum-
bian Observer fifteen hundred dollars! And the
declaration that Mr.. Buchanan proposed to fight
the opponents of General Jackson with their.own
weapons-that is. by intrigue, &c. This is denied.
and we cannot but believe, that Mr.. Eaton, in this
particular, msconceived Mr.. Buchanan--a7olt
will be remarked that the letter does not, in the
| smallest degree. go to raise a suspicion that Mr..
Clay made any proposition to General jackson
through Mr.. Buchanan ; and this, be it remembered
is the great question at issue between GEN. Jackson
and the public. --


| The editor oftbe Z" Courier published in Por-
tage, Ohio, says. We are well assured, that ut
least two-hrs of both branches of the next Legis-
laure of Ohio will be in favor of the reelection Of
Mr.. Adams. There seventeen members Of the
senate, whose term of service have not yet expred
tareLve ofwhom, and probably thirteen are admins
tration men. Of the nineteen districts from which
the senators are to be chosed at the approaching
election not less than twelve will give majortes in
favour of the administration. OF the representa-
tives to the next congress romthis stateeLeUea
in favour of the administration, and too opposed TO
it." So much for Ohio. q. S. Gazette.

OREENSVILLE, y. Y. OCt. o'


More Gold.-We have just seen small bar OF
very line Gold, exceeding in value one hundred and
fifty dollars, brought from Tiger river in Spartan
burg, where Mr.. James II. Randolph, is now wash
ing for this metal. This piece of Gold was not
found in one body, but consists Of several parcels
melted into one.

Your committee will also declare, that after ex-

reason Wny .uC niouN kiC'cAS' ~ any b'
he statesmen Dthe country protesting the same la
.itudinous construction.


Your committee will also declare, that, after ex-
amining all the proofs, they have still the most entire
confidence in the Integrity and honor Of the Secre.
tary Of State.


From the papers itappears that, in some parts OF
our country the result Of the late election in this
State was unexpected. II must be admitted that
MIR. Adams had been represented in the worst col
ors for three years. and that these representations
original and selected, had gone, perhaps, to every
village in the state while little, in comparison, Of
a contrary nature had been presented TO our citi-
zens.--Certain individuals, also, who had con-
siderable influence, we're known TO be members Of
the I" Combination in full standing: and this Cir
cum.,ance in addition to the former, was supposed
10 be decisive of the fate of Mr.. Adams in Dela-
ware.


But the truth Notwithstanding all the misrep-
reseptations of prostuted press--and all the la
bours of the Combination" asprants among us,
Delaware has not been at any one moment, friend
" to the election Of General Jackson in preference
to Mr. Adams Had not the people of this State
been able to form their sentiments on this sub
ject, they still would have remembered the denun-
Citations of the General which proceeded from this
same prostuted press, and these political asprans
and some of their tools. The people remembered
these things--and they will long remember them,
unless they willing to submit to further imposi-
tions.


Let, therefore, writers at distance not suppose
that they have "ga,ned" Delaware--for Delaware
was never in favour of General Jackson, notwth-
Standing althe labors of prosttuted press and its
Managers all the tales Of kremer Jackson, lsaacks,
Eaton, and company and all the misrepresentation
selected from the Kentucky Argus, Noahs Enquir-
er, and the whole host of =" improved presses, and
circulated semi-weekly, in all parts of the State.


1t is true, that there parts of the State which
need more fair, Just, and candid view of public
men and measures. 1t is true-that things as they
really are have not been presented to them but it
would be an unjust estimate of the sober sense, the
dsnterested feeling, and intelligence of the people
of Delaware, to suppose that they were incapable Of
discovering that the prominent leaders, in the war
waging against the Administration we're PERSON
ALL Interested Ill ulC cfcht VI tC Sohtcoi ACJ
have seen. nd we'll weighed this striking circum-
sance and they have told, even. those whom they
have delighted to honor, that they are FREEMEN,
not to be led or driven in this momentous question.
They have spoken amidst all the disadvantages un-
der which they have labored, by majority OF near
k 400; and they will hereafter speak, when pos
sessed Of more just and true state of things, with
more decision
